column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mrs.
#Text=Mladineo (Croatia): Croatia has aligned\r
#Text=itself with the statement made by the representative of\r
#Text=the United Kingdom on behalf of the European Union,\r
#Text=but I would like to add a few points based on Croatia's\r
#Text=specific experience and achievements on the matter.
#Text=At the outset, allow me, on behalf of my\r
#Text=delegation, to commend the Romanian presidency for\r
#Text=organizing this open debate to mark the fifth\r
#Text=anniversary of the adoption of Security Council\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000), on women and peace and\r
#Text=security.
#Text=Since 2000, the international community has\r
#Text=increasingly come to recognize not only how much\r
#Text=conflict particularly affects women and girls, but also\r
#Text=how often women hold the key to its peaceful\r
#Text=resolution.
#Text=It will be important to examine ways in\r
#Text=which the provisions of this important cross-cutting\r
#Text=resolution can be better implemented at the regional\r
#Text=and national levels.
#Text=Croatia welcomes the United Nations system-\r
#Text=wide action plan produced by the Secretary-General\r
#Text=(see S/2005/636), which aims at highlighting the\r
#Text=importance of gender perspectives in conflict\r
#Text=prevention and peacekeeping activities.
#Text=In order to\r
#Text=achieve success in the post-war confidence-building\r
#Text=process it is essential to include women as active\r
#Text=participants in post-conflict reintegration and\r
#Text=reconstruction.
#Text=That has also been borne out by\r
#Text=Croatia's experience.
#Text=The protection of women in armed conflict and\r
#Text=women's fundamental role in conflict prevention and\r
#Text=peacebuilding cannot be evaluated without taking into\r
#Text=account that women are among those most affected by\r
#Text=violence and the economic instability resulting from\r
#Text=armed conflict.
#Text=Yet, when it comes to negotiating\r
#Text=peace, post-war reconstruction and reconciliation,\r
#Text=women are grossly underrepresented.
#Text=We should\r
#Text=continue to press the main bodies of the United\r
#Text=Nations, particularly its funds and programmes, to\r
#Text=strengthen the participation of women in their work\r
#Text=and to streamline gender issues.
#Text=Post-conflict\r
#Text=transition, recovery and reconstruction cannot be\r
#Text=achieved if gender equality and the promotion of\r
#Text=women's rights are absent.
#Text=Croatia welcomes the increased involvement of\r
#Text=women in peacekeeping operations, especially among\r
#Text=human rights and humanitarian personnel, military\r
#Text=observers and civilian police.
#Text=In that connection, we\r
#Text=strongly encourage the practice of mainstreaming the\r
#Text=gender perspective into peacekeeping operations.
#Text=At\r
#Text=the same time, we must increase our efforts to improve\r
#Text=the protection of women in armed conflict, parallel to\r
#Text=acknowledging and enhancing their contribution to\r
#Text=peace processes and to rebuilding their communities.
#Text=The Commission for Gender Equality of the\r
#Text=Republic of Croatia - an intergovernmental\r
#Text=commission entrusted with creating policies and\r
#Text=coordinating all activities for the promotion of gender\r
#Text=equality - incorporated a chapter on women and\r
#Text=armed conflict in the national policy for the promotion\r
#Text=of gender equality for the period 2001-2005 and in its\r
#Text=implementation programme.
#Text=Both documents were\r
#Text=adopted by the Croatian parliament in December 2001.
#Text=Some tangible results have already been achieved\r
#Text=in pursuing the goals set out in the national policy.
#Text=One\r
#Text=such result was the inclusion of the study of\r
#Text=international humanitarian law and human rights in the\r
#Text=\r
#Text=curriculum of the Croatian military academy as an\r
#Text=integral part of the military education of the armed\r
#Text=forces.
#Text=Special emphasis is placed on the promotion\r
#Text=and protection of women's human rights and the\r
#Text=introduction of measures aimed at combating violence\r
#Text=against women in war, in armed conflict and during\r
#Text=post-conflict transition.
#Text=We seek to apply a gender perspective in\r
#Text=Croatia's participation in United Nations peacekeeping\r
#Text=operations.
#Text=During 2005, two Croatian women officers\r
#Text=have been serving in the peacekeeping missions in\r
#Text=India and Pakistan and in Cyprus.
#Text=Currently, five\r
#Text=women officers from the Croatian armed forces are\r
#Text=serving within the German contingent of the\r
#Text=International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan.
#Text=Preparations are taking place for a female officer to\r
#Text=serve as a military psychologist in the peacekeeping\r
#Text=mission in Haiti.
#Text=In addition, a captain of the Croatian\r
#Text=armed forces was the first female officer to take part in\r
#Text=the Military Observer Group in India and Pakistan.
#Text=Of course, the success of the application of the\r
#Text=principles and underlying themes of resolution 1325\r
#Text=(2000) rests with Member States.
#Text=In that regard, there\r
#Text=is more that we all can do to ensure that women can\r
#Text=fully and equally participate at all levels of decision-\r
#Text=making with regard to conflict-prevention and\r
#Text=peacebuilding.
